Why not just stop eating wheat? The stuff is poison to most people. Think carefully about "wheat" as a seed: it does not want to be eaten, it wants to be a new wheat plant. Nature did not create wheat for us to eat. Wheat has evolved to produce chemicals in the wheat "seed" that both protect the seed from being eaten, and digested, and to further the growth of the seed into a plant. None of this is intended by nature to be beneficial for seed eaters. The best one can hope for is to be able to tolerate those problematic chemical compounds n the short term.

Consider as well that people have been eating wheat in significant amounts only for the last 6,000 to 10,000 years, compared to the prior diet, which did not include wheat much, if at all. People did not evolve eating wheat, because it was simply not available. Even cows, natural herbivores of course, get sick when eating grains.

Yes, the wheat farmers will suffer, but there are other things to grow and eat. Unless you think it is your duty to eat wheat.

Want more information on wheat? Check out the "PanuBlog" and see what an MD who has studied the problem has to say. It is a logical analysis of the issue.

Richard

FOXDOG: your experience sounds like a typical paranoid episode induced by setting in a naive user of marijuana. These reactions are common, although usually not as severe as yours. This is about as bad as it gets, thank heaven. It wears off in a few hours, and if you don't confess to the nearest police officer that you're stoned, you probably won't suffer any permanent consequences.

To use this temporary reaction as an excuse to condemn marijuana is narcissistic. Other people are not going to be as badly affected as you. You're not the only person in the world.

India is surrounded by nuclear armed China & Pakistan. Both China & Pakistan have long standing disputes with India and both are dictatorships, China is dejure dictatorship of Chinese Communist Party & Pakistan a defacto dictatorship of Islamist Pakistan Army, in such a situation without China & Pakistan stopping production of nuclear fuel, Indian leaders cannot afford to commit suicide just to please the nuclear zealots of US. Other than a global treaty which is verifiable and has mechanism to prevent nuclear blackmail, global nuclear disarmament will remain a pipe dream. Is US ready to disarm China & Pakistan? Senator Nunn kindly stop day dreaming & kindly focus on how to prevent both China & Pakistan from global proliferation of nuclear weapons & technology.

"The Pakistanis insist that they have no choice. A nuclear deal that India signed with the United States during the Bush administration ended a long moratorium on providing India with the fuel and technology for desperately needed nuclear power plants.
Now, as critics of the arrangement point out, the agreement frees up older facilities that India can devote to making its own new generation of weapons..."

What a bunch of balonie!

USA is nervous about India growing out of the third world status, just like rich people get nervous when poor pesants who work for them become less dependant on them.

What do we do when we don't like our not-really-allies become stronger? We invade them. In this case we can't invade India, as they have no oil.

So the next best thing is to suit up their neighbors with nuclear weapons. If not for USA, how on earth did Pakistan come up with nuclear weapons within two weeks of India conducting nuclear test?
This is all for show and politics, I seriously doubt it's usefulness.

If the US would retaliate in the unfortunate occurrence of a nuclear attack,that is provided we would be able to do so. What would be the difference in eliminating what is a known threat before it happened? Having been trained professionally in armed conflict I was never taught to wait on your assailant to shoot you first then you shoot back!

I am not a person that would like to see any human loss of life; however if this must happen I'd rather see to it that the injury happened to the other side...

Aren't we in the 21st century? Nuclear arms is so '70s and no one other than inside the Beltway types really care about them anymore. Most countries, other than the lunatic fringe of the Middle East, realize that they are better off focusing on the immediate needs of their citizens rather than the bragging rights of nuclear capability. And even at that, let them annihilate each other with their handful of weapons if that is what they want.

The Administration should be fixing our domestic problems and ending the two wars we are currently fighting. Leave the past to others.

The biggest threat in the world regarding terrorists acquiring nuclear weapons is in Pakistan. The country is full of terrorist organizations and some of them are supported by the intelligence agency. It will be challenge to deal with this situation. President Obama is doing a great job of getting all the world leaders together and talk about the situation. This is real leadership.

Let me add my voice before the NYT (as is its wont when it comes to its quintessentially discriminatory articles against India) beats a hasty retreat by quickly refusing to accept more comments.

The tendency to hyphenate India and Pakistan is disingenous and reeks of hypocrisy. Whilst the NYT refuses to abandon its Quixotic pursuit, the world's largest democracy, undeniably vibrant and an emerging giant, hardly needs the condescending editorial approval of the likes of the NYT! However, the article's deliberate silence on India's impeccable track record on nuclear proliferation betrays its silent pimping for the high priests of "NPTology" at the NYT and elsewhere, who are yet to recover from the inking of the US-India nuclear deal.

The point, ultimately, is this. Nuclear foreign policy is seldom framed on a whim in a vacuum. The fundamental driver of US policy is India's emerging financial muscle. The US-India nuke deal is a windfall for many American corporations. Therefore, as long as India continues to prosper (and all indicators are that she will, despite genuine issues of poverty and other inequities within herself) and American companies are making money, articles such as this in the NYT or elsewhere are utterly impotent to change the course of things.

Well, now that these emergent nuclear powers know when,if, why and where the U.S. would strike in the event of,who knows when, where, if, why a nuclear attack would...Geez...I'm sleeping much more soundly than back in 1974 when MAD was still the order of the day.

1. The article failed to mention that India has a ``no first use" of nuclear weapons, which no other country has, not even USA.

2. Mr. Nunn said he would have insisted that USA negotiate with India to stop their production of weapons fuel. And why would India agree to that?

3. The article says that India, too, is making new weapons-grade plutonium. Do the author has any source or is making a guess.

I would like to make the following observation :
1. Pakistan has received billions of dollars of American aid since its formation 60 years ago
2. Over the last 6 decades, Pakistan's situation has been deteriorating - there is NO light at the end of the tunnel (Can the Americans see it?!)
3. Pakistan feeds and fosters Al queda and Taliban which have been operating out of its territory
4. Qixotically, it considers India, from which it was born, as its ONLY enemy
5. India, on the other hand, has China as a threat - it has fought a major war with China. China has laid claims to at least one Indian state.
6. India, the most diverse country in the world, has made huge economic contribution to the global economy whereas Pakistan has exported terrorism

Get rid of the military in Pakistan and the situation of that country will improve. And please stop equating India with Pakistan.

Charles, can you not read? Get real! Obama is doing what Bush should have done,however I'm willing to bet you that if we are threatened by any country Obama will retaliate in kind.

What does Obama mean when he refers to "all that nuclear material floating around out there"? Fissile materials are some of the heaviest metallic elements in the known universe, and therefore it is an absurd notion that this stuff would float anywhere on earth.

On a serious note - the president only knows what he has been told about nuclear weaponry, and we have to assume he paid attention in class and was able to assimilate the information. Personally, I don't believe he knows what he is talking about in regard to the technology and the need to develop updated weapons so we can remain a free nation that has been able to enjoy a relative measure of peace since Japan made it necessary for us to demonstrate just how awful thermonuclear devices are and how awesome a destructive force is unleashed with a relatively low yeild device like those used against the Japanese.

As long as one side is not willing to stop making these devices, failure to keep up with progress and fall behind to the point of obsolescence is dereliction of the duty of the president to defend the United States of America as a nation, as a people, and the Constitution that is the frame work of freedom all over the world.

Mr. President, the best course of action for you would be to do nothing since the situation is presently fairly stable and has been for the past time since 1946. Stop all the frantic scramble to destabilize the world and the government of the people, by the people and for the people because you are destroying what hundreds of thousands of people have died to preserve in our American way of life. We are not Europe, Asia, Africa or any other place on this planet - We are America, the place that everyone from all of those places comes to so they too can live free of opressive rule. If you keep going down the road you are on now, this country will degrade into a third world nation status and that would be because of things you have done.

The ball is in your court, sir. Don't let the American people down by throwing all that America is down the drain.
The South Asia nuke problem is serious business. Luckily for the United States and the world, we have an intelligent and thoughtful president at this important time in history.

Pakistan ought to be thermonuclearly defanged, ASAP. It presents an extreme danger, much greater than Iran (Pakistan has a history of aggression, Iran a much longer history of being attacked, but not striking out in the last few centuries).

After a nuclear exchange with India killing 100 million people or so, China, blinded by its contempt for democracy (similar to that the Nazis had) could well decide to strike victorious (but heavily mauled) India. Then the West would have to strike China.

This scenario, is, by far, the most probable, and most dangerous on earth.

The USA funded part of the nuclear weapons program of Pakistan, and long favored that American made theocracy, as a counter balance to India, and part of the general American strategy to use Muslim fundamentalism against democracy. 9/11 showed the short comings of such strategy. Time to correct all this. Forcing Pakistan to nuclearly disarm ought to be the number one priority, before North Korea, before Iran, before Israel...

I think it's time that we as a country and a people realize our discriminatory policies that are not helping us create any friends anywhere in the world. I think it's time that we realized that all human beings are created equal and treated them as such regardless of their economic status or religious affiliations.

We continue to remain mum about the world's most sophisticated nuclear weaponization program in the Middle-East, on one hand; and on the other, we try to act as the world's moral police when someone else tries to do what we ourselves have done many time over.

We as a people need to do some introspection to be able to arrive at a fair approach to this whole nuclear “issue”. What moral authority do we have to preach to others which we don't practice ourselves?

Forget health care. Forget the economy. If the brightest minds in this administration can start the process to keep us safe from nuclear attack, they'll have established a wonderful and enduring legacy.

I generally vote republican. Not based on social issues, as I think the democrats are more level headed on them. And not based on fiscal issues, because I think both parties have been willing to engage in a lot of deficit spending, which will cost me and my son more in the near and long term future. I vote republican because I've felt that thy have been stronger on defending the country.

But this administration has not dropped the ball on our defense, in fact quite the opposite (except for the Holder decisions on trying the Guantanamo detainees). They've acquitted themselves well in Iraq and Afghanistan. I don't pretend to know what's right in dealing with Iran, or how to keep the extremists on both sides of the Israeli/Palestinian conflict from making things worse.

I'm impressed with the president and his team. I look forward to voting for him if he continues to show progress in moving the world toward a less dangerous future.

I wish Mr. Obama all the best this week. I salute his efforts on our behalf.

It will be impossible to stop Iran from getting the bomb: its simply a matter of national pride for them.

Iran imagines itself a world player, and it sees a nuclear program as a must-have to be part of that club. To accept anything less than the bomb for Iran is to swallow its pride and accept a status of second best, which Iran will not do. Even with very harsh punishments from the international community, this will simply goad Iran to insist on getting the bomb even more. Its the psychology of pride: the more we try to punish Iran, the more Iran is determined to get the bomb, as a simple mark of pride. You can't humiliate Iran into dropping its nuclear program, you can only make Iran angrier and more insistent on getting it.

The question then is: how do you stop Iran from getting the bomb? And the answer is: you don't. With Libya, it was more about the ego of one man: Qaddafi. Qaddafi could be bargained with, and then the matter was dropped. But even if you got rid of all the hardliners in Iran, even if Iran experienced some sort of revolution by the students on the street, even then, Iran will still insist on getting the bomb. Ask those students, who despise Ahmadinejad and his Republican Guards, if Iran should get the bomb, and say will say: "of course, yes". What the students do, they do in the name of loving Iran, just as much as their polar opposites, the basiji, also love Iran: they all think Iran deserves the bomb. Its simple national pride.

We have to think about planning for a world with an Iranian bomb. Only because it is completely inevitable. But we can't make peace with that fact, because the idea of an Iranian bomb is frightening. You are talking about a country on the edge of popular revolution, and a power struggle going on between forces of a military dictatorship and grumpy old men who believe they interpret the will of God and are empowered by the country's constitution to rule by their interpretations.

So between the theocrats, the military junta, and the angry students, now you get people in that mix with their fingers on a big red button... in a volatile region of the world.

I honestly don't believe this can end well, I really don't. I try to be optimistic in life, but I am completely pessimistic about the implications of the coming reality of an Iranian bomb. It's genuinely frightening.
